text: hey everybody Thomas Joseph here now you
may not know a Gen woz by its name but
it is a classic sponge cake that is used
as the base for many things like jelly
rolls petit fours and layer cakes
what makes this cake so unique is that
it relies solely on air for its
leavening so no baking soda no baking
powder now some people have trouble with
the genoise or a sponge cake they find
that they're too dense or they collapse
but today I'm going to show you some
tricks behind making a gen waz to start
off five whole eggs this is where the
leavening comes from these eggs to this
add a half a cup plus 2 tablespoons of
superfine sugar I have a pot of
simmering water here place this mixture
over the simmering water and whisk until
the eggs are warmed and the sugar is
dissolved the added heat allows the eggs
to expand in volume so it's been a few
minutes in a way to test to see if that
sugar is dissolved is to actually dip
your fingers in and see if you feel any
granules of sugar the sugar is
completely dissolved so this goes right
on to the stand mixer with a whisk
attachment this goes on high speed until
it's quadrupled in volume and that will
take about five minutes
you can see how light our beautiful egg
and sugar mixture is and now to finish
the cake I have six tablespoons of
browned butter that is still very warm
add one teaspoon of vanilla extract to
this give it a slight stir and now take
your egg mixture and about a cup of it
mix into your warm brown butter vanilla
mixture and this little trick of
combining the fat with this egg batter
helps keep the volume of the cake a lot
of recipes call for you adding the fat
down the side of the bowl and folding it
into the total batter itself but this
really helps to maintain the volume and
now the remaining egg mixture add flour
so I have 2/3 of a cup of cake flour
which is a very finely ground flour it
has a lower protein content than
all-purpose flour and a half of a cup of
corn starch sift it right over the top
of the egg sugar mixture
you don't want any clumps of flour in
your batter just press it right through
the sieve and now fold your mixture into
the egg folding is bringing the batter
from under up and over think about like
the letter J that's the kind of the
motion you're creating and I'm turning
the bowl as I'm folding now you want to
do this very gently because you don't
want to deflate all of that air you just
created
Asian Waze differs from a sponge cake in
that as Jen Waze uses whole eggs that
are whipped for the volume whereas a
sponge cake has the egg yolk in the egg
whites separated and whipped and then
combined later on in the process
now add the butter egg mixture into this
and fold it together make sure your oven
is preheated to 350 degrees Fahrenheit
with the rack in the center of the oven
so I have a 9 by 3 inch pan coated with
nonstick cooking spray and lined with
parchment and then sprayed again pour
the batter into the pan and get this
right into the oven don't open the oven
wallis baking
this cake will collapse if you do that
and this bakes for 20 to 30 minutes
until a toothpick inserted into the
center comes out nice and clean so right
into the oven after 30 minutes of baking
make sure that you take your cake out of
the oven and immediately turn it out
onto a wire rack to cool completely I
just want to show you what the inside
looks like because that really is the
signature Jen was that light delicate
crumb you can see how fine the texture
is is light its delicate its moist from
that wonderful butter so layer it with
your favorite frosting and there you
have it guys as Jen watch a cake for all
occasions
